member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IFormattableNetMap
member.summary: Provides functionality for formatting a NetMap object into a String representation.
member.remarks: This interface adds a method to the interface and defines a minimum set of format specifiers for formatting NetMap objects.

member.name: M:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IFormattableNetMap.ToString
member.overloads: Formats the value of the current instance.
member.summary: Formats the value of the current instance using the default format.
member.returns: The formatted string.
member.remarks: This is the same as ("G").

member.name: M:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IFormattableNetMap.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Formats the value of the current instance using a specified format.
member.param: The specifying the format to use, or null or an empty string to use the default format. See for the available formats.
member.returns: The formatted string.

member.name: M:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IFormattableNetMap.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Formats the value of the current instance using a specified format and format provider.
member.param: The specifying the format to use, or null or an empty string to use the default format. The minimum set of supported formats are listed in the remarks.
The to use to format the value, or null to use the format information from the current locale setting of the operating system. The implementation may ignore this parameter.
member.returns: The formatted string.
member.remarks:
The implementation may ignore .
The implementation must support the following values. It may support additional formats as well.
Format Results
G
Default format, includes only an instance summary. An instance summary may be an object ID or name, for example.
P
Includes all public properties, each on a separate line. For collection properties, only the item count is included.
D
Includes all public properties, each on a separate line. For collection properties, a summary of each item in the collection is included, each on a separate line.
null
Same as G.
Empty string ("")
Same as G.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IIdentityProvider
member.summary: Provides object identity.
member.remarks: Classes that provide information for identifying an instance should implement this interface.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IIdentityProvider.Name
member.summary: Gets the object's name.
member.value: The object's name, as a String. Can be null. The default value is null.
member.remarks:
The name is optional and is set by the application.
Names are case sensitive. The names "Mary" and "mary" are different, for example.
The core NetMap system does not enforce uniqueness of names. It is possible to have two items with the same name in the same collection.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IIdentityProvider.ID
member.summary: Gets the object's ID.
member.value: The object's ID, as an Int32.
member.remarks:
The ID is set when the object is created. It must be unique among all objects of the same category for the duration of the process in which NetMap is running. ("Category" means graph, vertex, or edge.) No two vertices can have the same ID, for example, although a vertex and edge can have the same ID.
If an object is cloned, the copy must have an ID different from that of the original.
If the object is saved to persistent storage and then loaded from that storage, the loaded object must have an ID different from that of the original.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IMetadataProvider
member.summary: Provides metadata.
member.remarks:
Classes that provide metadata for storing application-defined information should implement this interface.
Metadata can be stored as a single via the property, or as key/value pairs via the method, or both.

member.name: M:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IMetadataProvider.ContainsKey(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether a metadata value with a specified key exists.
member.param: The value's key. Can't be null or empty, and can't start with a tilde (~).
member.returns: true if there is a metadata value with the key , false if not.
member.remarks:
If true is returned, the metadata value can be retrieved with or one of its variants.
Keys that start with a tilde (~) are reserved by the NetMap system for internal use.

member.name: M:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IMetadataProvider.RemoveKey(System.String)
member.summary: Removes a specified metadata key if it exists.
member.param: The key to remove. Can't be null or empty, and can't start with a tilde (~).
member.returns:
true if the metadata key was removed, false if there is no such key.
Keys that start with a tilde (~) are reserved by the NetMap system for internal use.

The value to set. Can be null.
member.remarks:
The application can store arbitrary metadata by adding key/value pairs via . The values can be retrieved with or one of its variants. The keys are of type and the values are of type .
If you want to store just a single metadata object, use the property instead.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys
member.summary: Contains metadata keys that are reserved for internal use by the NetMap system.
member.remarks:
The reserved metadata keys defined within this class can't be used by application code.
See for information on the metadata scheme used by NetMap.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.FirstChar
member.summary: All reserved keys start with this character.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.EdgeWeight
member.summary: Key added to an edge to specify an edge weight.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.ToolTip
member.summary:
Key to pass to to set a vertex's tooltip when using the NetMapControl. The value must be a String.
For tooltips to be visible, you must set NetMapControl.UseToolTips to true. The default is false.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.IsSelected
member.summary: Key to pass to to select a vertex or edge when the MultiSelectionGraphDrawer is being used. The value is null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.HitTestArea
member.summary:
Key added to a vertex to aid in hit-testing. The value is the Microsoft.NetMap.Visualization.HitTestArea object that defines the area occupied by the vertex.
Hiding a vertex by adding the key to it automatically clears the key. This prevents a hidden vertex from responding positively to a hit test.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.Hide
member.summary:
Key added to a vertex or edge to hide it. The value is null.
Hiding a vertex by adding this key to it automatically clears any key that might have been set on the vertex. This prevents a hidden vertex from responding positively to a hit test.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerColor
member.summary: Key added to a vertex or edge to force it to be a specified color. The key's value is a Color.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerAlpha
member.summary: Key added to a vertex or edge to force it to be a specified transparency. The key's value is an Int32 between 0 (transparent) and 255 (opaque).

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerVertexShape
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to force it to be a specified shape. The key's value is a VertexDrawer.VertexShape.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerVertexRadius
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to force it to be a specified radius. The key's value is a Single between VertexDrawer.MinimumRadius and VertexDrawer.MaximumRadius.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerVertexImage
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to force it to be drawn as an image instead of a shape. The key's value is a System.Drawing.Image.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerVertexPrimaryLabel
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to force it to be drawn as a rectangle containing a text label instead of a shape. The key's value is a System.String. and may be specified in any combination.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerVertexPrimaryLabelFillColor
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to force it to have a specified fill color. The key's value is a Color. Used only if is specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerVertexPrimaryLabelDrawInfo
member.summary: Key added to a vertex by PerVertexWithLabelDrawer.PreDrawVertex when a primary label has been specified. The value is a PerVertexWithLabelDrawer.PrimaryLabelDrawInfo object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerVertexSecondaryLabel
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to force a text label to be drawn near it. The key's value is a System.String. and may be specified in any combination.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerVertexDrawerPrecedence
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to specify which vertex drawer should be used for the vertex.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.PerEdgeWidth
member.summary: Key added to an edge to force it to be a specified width. The key's value is an Int32.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.LayoutBaseLayoutComplete
member.summary: Key added to the graph after it has been laid out. The key's value is of type Rectangle and stores the graph's layout rectangle.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.LayOutTheseVerticesOnly
member.summary: Key added to a graph to tell the layout algorithm to lay out only a specified set of vertices. The key's value is an IVertex array containing the vertices to lay out. When this key is present on the graph, the layout completely ignores the graph's vertices that are not in the specified array.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.LockVertexLocation
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to tell the layout algorithm to leave the vertex at its current location. The key's value is a Boolean. The layout may include the vertex in its overall layout calculations, but it cannot move the vertex.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.CircleLayoutCircleDrawn
member.summary: Key added to the graph after it has been completely drawn. The value is null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.SpiralLayoutSpiralDrawn
member.summary: Key added to the graph after it has been completely drawn. The value is null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.SinusoidLayoutSinusoidDrawn
member.summary: Key added to the graph after it has been completely drawn. The value is null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.GridLayoutGridDrawn
member.summary: Key added to the graph after it has been completely drawn. The value is null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.FruchtermanReingoldLayoutSelectivelyRandomize
member.summary: Key added to the graph to tell the layout to randomize the locations of only those vertices whose location is set to LayoutBase.RandomizeThisLocation. If this key is not present, all locations are randomized. The value is null.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.FruchtermanReingoldLayoutTagStorage
member.summary: Key added to each vertex to temporarily store the vertex's Tag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.SugiyamaComputedRadius
member.summary: SugiyamaLayout uses VertexDrawer.Radius as an initial radius for the vertex circles, then computes an actual radius that probably differs from the initial value. It stores the computed radius in the IGraph's metadata in a key named SugiyamaComputedRadius The type of the key's value is Single.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.SugiyamaCurvePoints
F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.SugiyamaEndpoint
member.summary:
For each edge, SugiyamaLayout computes an endpoint on the second vertex's circle and stores it in the edge's metadata in a key named SugiyamaEndpoint. The type of the key's value is PointF. The line from the last curve point to the endpoint should be drawn with code similar to the following:
oGraphics.DrawLine(oPen, aoCurvePoints[aoCurvePoints.Length - 1], oEndpoint );

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.SugiyamaGleeNode
member.summary: SugiyamaLayout uses SugiyamaGleeNode to temporarily store a NetMap vertex's corresponding GLEE node in the NetMap vertex's metadata. The type of the key's value is Microsoft.Glee.Node.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.SugiyamaGleeEdge
member.summary: SugiyamaLayout uses SugiyamaGleeEdge to temporarily store a NetMap edge's corresponding GLEE edge in the NetMap edge's metadata. The type of the key's value is Microsoft.Glee.Edge.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.GraphInfoViewerListViewItem
member.summary: The DesktopApplication.GraphInfoViewer adds this key to each vertex and edge in the graph. The value is the ListViewItem in the GraphInfoViewer that corresponds to the vertex or edge.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.Marked
member.summary: Key added to a vertex or edge to "mark" it. The value is true or false. The meaning of marking is up to the application. None of the NetMap core or visualization components pay attention to this key.

member.name: F:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.ReservedMetadataKeys.CustomContextMenuItems
member.summary: Key added to a vertex to add custom menu items to the vertex's context menu in the graph. The value is an array of KeyValue<String,String>. For each element, the key is the custom menu item text and the value is the custom menu item action.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Edge
member.summary: Provides a default edge implementation.
member.remarks:
An edge is a connection between two vertices in the same graph. An edge can be directed or undirected. A directed edge has a front and a back.
An edge always connects two vertices. Although an edge can be created before it is added to a graph, it can't be created without specifying the vertices it connects. An edge can be added only to the graph that contains the edge's vertices.
An can be created via its constructor and then added to a graph via Graph.Edges., or created and added to a graph at the same time via Graph.Edges..
An edge is immutable, meaning that its vertices can't be removed. An edge can be removed from a graph and disposed of, but once the edge is removed, the edge is unusable. Attempting to access the edge's properties or methods will lead to unpredictable results.
This class can be used as-is in many graphing applications. You can also customize it via inheritance, or implement your own edge class from scratch. All edge classes must implement the interface. If you implement an edge class, you may also want to implement a corresponding class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IEdge
member.summary: Represents an edge.
member.remarks:
An edge is a connection between two vertices in the same graph. An edge can be directed or undirected. A directed edge has a front and a back.
An edge always connects two vertices. Although an edge can be created before it is added to a graph, it can't be created without specifying the vertices it connects. An edge can be added only to the graph that contains the edge's vertices.
An edge can be created via and then added to a graph via IGraph.Edges., or created and added to a graph at the same time via IGraph.Edges..
An edge is immutable, meaning that its vertices can't be removed. An edge can be removed from a graph and disposed of, however.
The NetMap system includes an implementation that can be used as-is in many graphing applications. You can also derive a class from or implement your own custom edge class from scratch. The only requirement is that your custom class must implement .
If you implement a custom edge class, you may also want to implement to allow the NetMap system to create instances of your custom edge. For example, the IGraphTransformer.Transform method takes an optional argument that specifies the type of the edges in the transformed graph.

member.name: M:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IEdge.Clone(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.overloads: Creates a copy of the edge.
member.summary: Creates a copy of the edge, making the copy the same type as the original.
member.param: If true, the key/value pairs that were set with are copied to the new edge. (This is a shallow copy. The objects pointed to by the original values are NOT cloned.) If false, the key/value pairs are not copied.

If true, the property on the new edge is set to the same value as in the original edge. (This is a shallow copy. The object pointed to by the original is NOT cloned.) If false, the property on the new edge is set to null.
member.returns: The copy of the edge, as an .
member.remarks:
The new edge is of the same type as the original. It is connected to the same vertices as the original edge. Its is set to the same value as the original's, but it is assigned a new .
The new edge can be added only to the same graph.

members.member:
Gets a value indicating whether the edge is parallel to a specified edge.
Edge to test.
true if the edge is parallel to , false if not.
If the edges do not connect the same vertices, they are not parallel or anti-parallel. If they do connect the same vertices, they are parallel or anti-parallel, depending on the directedness of the graph and the edges. This is shown in the following table.
Graph Directedness Edge 1 Edge 2 Edge 1 Parallel to Edge 2? Edge 1 Anti-Parallel to Edge 2?
Directed (A->B) (A->B) Yes No
Directed (A->B) (B->A) No Yes
Undirected (A,B) (A,B) Yes No
Mixed (A,B) (A,B) Yes No
Mixed (A,B) (A->B) Yes No
Mixed (A,B) (B->A) Yes No
Mixed (A->B) (A,B) Yes No
Mixed (A->B) (A->B) Yes No
Mixed (A->B) (B->A) No Yes
Mixed (B->A) (A,B) Yes No
Mixed (B->A) (A->B) No Yes
Mixed (B->A) (B->A) Yes No
TODO: "A simple graph is one that contains no loops or parallel edges, where more than one edge connects two given vertices,"

member.summary: Sorts a collection of vertices on a specified metadata value.
member.typeparam: The type of the values that will be sorted on.
member.remarks:
Use this class when you want to sort a collection of vertices on a metadata value. Set the metadata value on each vertex in the collection, then call one of the methods.
The methods optimize sort performance by caching the metadata values instead of reading them every time two vertices are compared.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.VertexCollection
member.summary: Provides a default vertex collection implementation.
member.remarks:
This is a collection of objects that implement the interface. You can add vertices to the collection, remove them, access a vertex, and enumerate all vertices.
This collection class is used by the class to implement its collection. If you implement your own graph class, you can use this class for the collection, customize it via inheritance, or implement your own vertex collection from scratch. All vertex collection classes must implement the interface.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertexCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of vertices.
member.remarks:
This is a collection of objects that implement the interface. You can add vertices to the collection, remove them, access a vertex, and enumerate all vertices.
The NetMap system includes a implementation that can be used as-is in many graphing applications. You can also derive a class from or implement your own custom vertex collection class from scratch. The only requirement is that your custom class must implement IVertexCollection.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.MetadataProvider
member.summary: Provides metadata for an instance of a class that implements .
member.remarks:
This can be used by a client class that must implement the interface. It stores the Tag and all arbitrary key/value pairs for one instance of the client class.
Important Note:
The key/value pairs are stored in a LinkedList. To reduce memory usage, this class derives from LinkedList instead of storing a private reference to a LinkedList. However, none of the public properties or methods of LinkedList should be called by the client. The only properties and methods that should be called are those that are defined in this derived class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IEdgeCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of edges.
member.remarks:
This is a collection of objects that implement the interface. You can add edges to the collection, remove them, access an edge, and enumerate all edges.
The NetMap system includes an implementation that can be used as-is in many graphing applications. You can also derive a class from or implement your own custom edge collection class from scratch. The only requirement is that your custom class must implement IEdgeCollection.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph.
member.remarks:
A graph has a collection of and a collection of that connect the . The property specifies the type of edges that can be added to the graph.
Any class that represents a graph must implement this interface.
The NetMap system includes a implementation that can be used as-is in many graphing applications. You can also derive a class from or implement your own custom graph class from scratch. The only requirement is that your custom class must implement .
If you implement a custom graph class, you may also want to implement to allow the NetMap system to create instances of your custom graph. For example, the IGraphTransformer.Transform method takes an optional argument that specifies the type of the transformed graph.

member.returns: true if the graph imposes all of the restrictions specified by .
member.remarks:

Use to return all of the graph's restrictions.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IGraph.PerformExtraValidations
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag specifying whether extra but possibly slow validations are performed.
member.value: true to perform extra validations, false otherwise. The default value is false.
member.remarks:
When this property is set to true, the graph should perform extra validations during certain operations. For example, when a vertex is added to the collection, the graph might check whether the vertex already exists in the collection and throw an exception if it does.
Important note: The extra validations might be very slow, and therefore this property should be set to true only during development or after an unexpected problem occurs and the problem needs to be diagnosed. Depending on the implementation, checking whether a vertex already exists in the collection might be an O(n) operation, for example.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IDGenerator
member.summary: Generates a sequence of unique IDs.
member.remarks:
Call to get a unique integer ID. By default, generates a simple integer sequence that starts at 1.
This class can be used to generate unique IDs for graphs, vertices, and edges. The class responsible for creating objects of one of these types should define a static field of type , then call every time an object of that type is created. This results in independent sequences for each type.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.EdgeCollection
member.summary: Provides a default edge collection implementation.
member.remarks:
This is a collection of objects that implement the interface. You can add edges to the collection, remove them, access an edge, and enumerate all edges.
This collection class is used by the class to implement its collection. If you implement your own graph class, you can use this class for the collection, customize it via inheritance, or implement your own edge collection from scratch. All edge collection classes must implement the interface.

member.summary: Gets an array of a vertex's incoming or outgoing edges.

true to include the vertex's incoming edges.
true to include the vertex's outgoing edges.
member.returns: An array of the vertex's zero or more incoming or outgoing edges (or both), as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An incoming edge is either a directed edge that has the vertex at its front, or an undirected edge connected to the vertex.
An outgoing edge is either a directed edge that has the vertex at its back, or an undirected edge connected to the vertex.
If there are no such edges, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.
This method is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to .

member.name: M:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.EdgeCollection.GetPredecessorOrSuccessorVertices(Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets an array of a vertex's predecessor or successor vertices, or both.
member.param: to get predecessor or successor vertices for.
true to include the vertex's predecessor vertices.
true to include the vertex's successor vertices.
member.returns: An array of the vertex's zero or more predecessor or successor vertices, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
A predecessor vertex is a vertex at the other side of an incoming edge. (An incoming edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its front, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.)
A successor vertex is a vertex at the other side of an outgoing edge. (An outgoing edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its back, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.)
If there are no such vertices, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.
This method is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to .

member.summary: Contains methods that check method arguments and property values.
member.remarks:
This can be used by a class that wants to check values passed to its property setters and arguments passed to its methods. The CheckXXX() methods in this class throw an exception if a parameter value or method argument is invalid.
This class is marked internal to avoid compiler error CS0433 ("The type ... exists in both ...") when an executable references two or more assemblies that use this class.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Graph.PerformExtraValidations
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag specifying whether extra but possibly slow validations are performed.
member.value: true to perform extra validations, false otherwise. The default value is false. A value of true can dramatically slow graph operations.
member.remarks:
When this property is set to true, the graph performs extra validations during certain operations. For example, when a vertex is added to the collection, the graph checks whether the vertex already exists in the collection and throws an exception if it does.
Important note: The extra validations can be very slow, and therefore this property should be set to true only during development or after an unexpected problem occurs and the problem needs to be diagnosed. For example, checking whether a vertex already exists in the collection is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of vertices in the graph.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex
member.summary: Provides a default vertex implementation.
member.remarks:
A vertex, also known as a node, is a point in a graph that can be connected to other vertices in the same graph. The connections are called edges.
A can be created via its constructor and then added to a graph via IGraph.Vertices., or created and added to a graph at the same time via IGraph.Vertices..
A vertex can be added to one graph only. It cannot be added to a second graph unless it is first removed from the first graph.
This class can be used as-is in many graphing applications. You can also customize it via inheritance, or implement your own vertex class from scratch. All vertex classes must implement the interface. If you implement a vertex class, you may also want to implement a corresponding class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertex
member.summary: Represents a vertex.
member.remarks:
A vertex, also known as a node, is a point in a graph that can be connected to other vertices in the same graph. The connections are called edges.
A vertex can be created via and then added to a graph via IGraph.Vertices., or created and added to a graph at the same time via IGraph.Vertices..
A vertex can be added to one graph only. It cannot be added to a second graph unless it is first removed from the first graph.
The NetMap system includes a implementation that can be used as-is in many graphing applications. You can also derive a class from or implement your own custom vertex class from scratch. The only requirement is that your custom class must implement .
If you implement a custom vertex class, you may also want to implement to allow the NetMap system to create instances of your custom vertex. For example, the IGraphTransformer.Transform method takes an optional argument that specifies the type of the vertices in the transformed graph.

member.overloads: Creates a copy of the vertex.
member.summary: Creates a copy of the vertex, making the copy the same type as the original.
member.param: If true, the key/value pairs that were set with are copied to the new vertex. (This is a shallow copy. The objects pointed to by the original values are NOT cloned.) If false, the key/value pairs are not copied.

If true, the property on the new vertex is set to the same value as in the original vertex. (This is a shallow copy. The object pointed to by the original is NOT cloned.) If false, the property on the new vertex is set to null.
member.returns: The copy of the vertex, as an .
member.remarks:
The new vertex is of the same type as the original. It has no edges connected to it. Its is set to the same value as the original's, but it is assigned a new . Its is null and its is the default value of .
The new vertex can be added to the same graph or to a different graph.

member.summary: Gets the graph that owns the vertex.
member.value: The graph that owns the vertex, as an , or null if the vertex does not belong to a graph.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertex.IncomingEdges
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's incoming edges.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more incoming edges, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An incoming edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its front, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is considered one incoming edge.
If there are no incoming edges, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertex.OutgoingEdges
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's outgoing edges.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more outgoing edges, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An outgoing edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its back, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is considered one outgoing edge.
If there are no outgoing edges, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertex.IncidentEdges
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's incident edges.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more incident edges, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An incident edge is an edge that is connected to the vertex.
The returned array is the union of the and arrays.
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is considered one incident edge.
If there are no incident edges, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertex.Degree
member.summary: Gets the vertex's degree.
member.value: The vertex's degree, as an Int32.
member.remarks:
The degree of a vertex is the number of edges that are incident to it. (An incident edge is an edge that is connected to this vertex.)
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is considered one incident edge.
This property returns the same value as .Length.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertex.PredecessorVertices
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's predecessor vertices.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more predecessor vertices, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
A predecessor vertex is a vertex at the other side of an incoming edge. (An incoming edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its front, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.)
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is always considered an incoming edge. Therefore, if there is an edge that connects this vertex to itself, then this vertex is included in the returned array.
The predecessor vertices in the returned array are unique. If two or more edges connect this vertex with another vertex, the other vertex is included once only.
If there are no predecessor vertices, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertex.SuccessorVertices
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's successor vertices.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more successor vertices, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
A successor vertex is a vertex at the other side of an outgoing edge. (An outgoing edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its back, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.)
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is always considered an outgoing edge. Therefore, if there is an edge that connects this vertex to itself, then this vertex is included in the returned array.
The successor vertices in the returned array are unique. If two or more edges connect this vertex with another vertex, the other vertex is included once only.
If there are no successor vertices, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.IVertex.AdjacentVertices
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's adjacent vertices.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more adjacent vertices, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An adjacent vertex is a vertex at the other side of an incident edge. (An incident edge is an edge that is connected to the vertex.)
The returned collection is the union of the and collections.
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is always considered an incident edge. Therefore, if there is an edge that connects this vertex to itself, then this vertex is included in the returned array.
The adjacent vertices in the returned array are unique. If two or more edges connect this vertex with another vertex, the other vertex is included once only.
If there are no adjacent vertices, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.ParentGraph
member.summary: Gets the graph that owns the vertex.
member.value: The graph that owns the vertex, as an , or null if the vertex does not belong to a graph.
member.remarks: This is a read-only property. When the vertex is added to a graph, this property is automatically set to that graph. If the vertex is removed from the graph, this property is set to null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.IncomingEdges
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's incoming edges.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more incoming edges, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An incoming edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its front, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is considered one incoming edge.
If there are no incoming edges, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.
This property is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to this vertex.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.OutgoingEdges
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's outgoing edges.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more outgoing edges, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An outgoing edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its back, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is considered one outgoing edge.
If there are no outgoing edges, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.
This property is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to this vertex.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.IncidentEdges
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's incident edges.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more incident edges, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An incident edge is an edge that is connected to the vertex.
The returned array is the union of the and arrays.
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is considered one incident edge.
If there are no incident edges, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.
This property is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to this vertex.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.Location
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertex's location.
member.value: The vertex's location as a . The default value is cref="PointF.Empty" />.
member.remarks: This property is set when the graph is laid out by ILayout.LayOutGraph and is read when the graph is drawn.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.Degree
member.summary: Gets the vertex's degree.
member.value: The vertex's degree, as an Int32.
member.remarks:
The degree of a vertex is the number of edges that are incident to it. (An incident edge is an edge that is connected to this vertex.)
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is considered one incident edge.
This property returns the same value as .Length.
This property is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to this vertex.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.PredecessorVertices
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's predecessor vertices.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more predecessor vertices, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
A predecessor vertex is a vertex at the other side of an incoming edge. (An incoming edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its front, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.)
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is always considered an incoming edge. Therefore, if there is an edge that connects this vertex to itself, then this vertex is included in the returned array.
The predecessor vertices in the returned array are unique. If two or more incoming edges connect this vertex with another vertex, the other vertex is included once only.
If there are no predecessor vertices, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.
This property is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to this vertex.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.SuccessorVertices
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's successor vertices.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more successor vertices, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
A successor vertex is a vertex at the other side of an outgoing edge. (An outgoing edge is either a directed edge that has this vertex at its back, or an undirected edge connected to this vertex.)
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is always considered an outgoing edge. Therefore, if there is an edge that connects this vertex to itself, then this vertex is included in the returned array.
The successor vertices in the returned array are unique. If two or more outgoing edges connect this vertex with another vertex, the other vertex is included once only.
If there are no successor vertices, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.
This property is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to this vertex.

member.name: P:Microsoft.NetMap.Core.Vertex.AdjacentVertices
member.summary: Gets an array of the vertex's adjacent vertices.
member.value: An array of the vertex's zero or more adjacent vertices, as an array of objects.
member.remarks:
An adjacent vertex is a vertex at the other side of an incident edge. (An incident edge is an edge that is connected to the vertex.)
The returned collection is the union of the and collections.
A self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) is always considered an incident edge. Therefore, if there is an edge that connects this vertex to itself, then this vertex is included in the returned array.
The adjacent vertices in the returned array are unique. If two or more edges connect this vertex with another vertex, the other vertex is included once only.
If there are no adjacent vertices, the returned array is empty. The returned value is never null.
This property is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of edges incident to this vertex.

member.summary: Gets or sets the first node in the vertex's group of incident edges.
member.value: First node in the vertex's group of incident edges, or null if the vertex has no incident edges.
member.remarks: This is used by , which maintains the incident edge groups for all vertices.
